results.title: A Cook's tour
results.creator_credit: Bryan Chipperfield, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Bryan Chipperfield saw no action during his service in the air force. Posted to Calgary in Canada, Chipperfield was able to enjoy skiing, boating and playing sports. Keeping up to date with the war through reading the paper, he knew he may be asked to ‘play his part’ at any time.

Read by fellow veteran Bill Medlyn for Bryan Chipperfield
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bryan Chipperfield, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Bribie
results.creator_credit: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kevin Brady sets the record straight on the Battle of Bribie, considered to be the closest Australia got to losing a battle in Vietnam. His “digger’s account” illustrates the major obstacles and the bravery shown by the men, who were met with gunfire on landing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Interview with John Balloch
results.brief_description: John Balloch was at school when war was declared. Even so, he couldn’t wait to sign up. He wanted to be a fighter pilot, flying alone. He tells of his training and time serving in the RAAF during World War II and pays tribute to those lost, both to the enemy and accidents.

results.title: Becoming an Australian
results.creator_credit: George Logan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It wasn’t until George Logan served in the army overseas that he felt like a true Australian. Serving as an infantryman in Malaya and Vietnam, it was the values of mateship, care and concern for others that remain with Logan today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Logan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Interview with Colin Bannister
results.brief_description: In 1950, Colin Bannister sailed from Syndey to Singapore to defend the Malayan Government against an uprising in what was called ‘The Malayan Emergency’. Bannister’s time in Malaya has taught him about power and the important things in life.
results.description: In 1950, Colin Bannister sailed from Syndey to Singapore to defend the Malayan Government against an uprising in what was called ‘The Malayan Emergency’. Bannister’s time in Malaya has taught him about power and the important things in life.

results.title: An Interview with Jan McCarthy
results.brief_description: Jan McCarthy traces her career path of nursing, how it took her overseas and her time in the army, posted in Vietnam and Singapore. In Singapore, McCarthy became a Major and was later promoted to Colonel. She has no regrets about serving in the army and sees it as one big family.
results.description: Jan McCarthy traces her career path of nursing, how it took her overseas and her time in the army, posted in Vietnam and Singapore. In Singapore, McCarthy became a Major and was later promoted to Colonel. She has no regrets about serving in the army and sees it as one big family.
description_for_label: Jan McCarthy traces her career path of nursing, how it took her overseas and her time in the army, posted in Vietnam and Singapore. In Singapore, McCarthy became a Major and was later promoted to Colonel. She has no regrets about serving in the army and sees it as one big family.

results.title: Always a survivor
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Catterall and ACMI
results.brief_description: When David Catterall returned from the horrors of the Vietnam War, he found his personal and professional life disintergrating. It was then that Catterall discovered the supportive community made up by his fellow returned soldiers and credits them with enabling him to pull through some of the darkest moments of his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Catterall and ACMI

It was then that Catterall discovered the supportive community made up by his fellow returned soldiers and credits them with enabling him to pull through some of the darkest moments of his life.

It was then that Catterall discovered the supportive community made up by his fellow returned soldiers and credits them with enabling him to pull through some of the darkest moments of his life.

results.title: An Interview with Laurie Price
results.creator_credit: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Laurie Price is one of the remaining third of those Australians who served in Korea. He provides sharp detail of the work he performed there on the airfields, the distractions and tensions, even between allies. While the war is long over, it continues to affect Price even today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Interview with George Derham
results.creator_credit: George Derham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: George Derham was called up to serve for Australia on the 4/4/44. He joined the Australian Navy and recalls his time there, of fitting in and standing out. Collecting Australian prisoners of war in Japan, two images affected Derham greatly - that of Tokyo after the extensive firebombing by the US, and the emaciated state of the prisoners of war. Despite this, Derham sees military life as a valuable part of his development and works hard to assist returned soldiers and their families.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Derham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: George Derham was called up to serve for Australia on the 4/4/44. He joined the Australian Navy and recalls his time there, of fitting in and standing out. Collecting Australian prisoners of war in Japan, two images affected Derham greatly - that of Tokyo after the extensive firebombing by the US, and the emaciated state of the prisoners of war. Despite this, Derham sees military life as a valuable part of his development and works hard to assist returned soldiers and their families.

Collecting Australian prisoners of war in Japan, two images affected Derham greatly - that of Tokyo after the extensive firebombing by the US, and the emaciated state of the prisoners of war. Despite this, Derham sees military life as a valuable part of his development and works hard to assist returned soldiers and their families.

results.title: Reminiscing
results.creator_credit: Alf Thornton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alf Thornton fondly recalls his time serving in the Australian Navy during World War II, when letting your mates down was more feared than being killed. When Thornton returned, he spent most of his time trying to regain his lost youth but eventually found an anchor on the H.M.A.S. Castlemaine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alf Thornton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Alf Thornton fondly recalls his time serving in the Australian Navy during World War II, when letting your mates down was more feared than being killed. When Thornton returned, he spent most of his time trying to regain his lost youth but eventually found an anchor on the H.M.A.S. Castlemaine.

When Thornton returned, he spent most of his time trying to regain his lost youth but eventually found an anchor on the H.M.A.S. Castlemaine.
